title: 109_hr4844
content: The "Federal Election Integrity Act of 2006" requires voters to provide photo identification. The "Federal Election Integrity Act of 2006" mandates voters to present photo identification when receiving a ballot. The "Federal Election Integrity Act of 2006" requires individuals to show a government-issued photo ID to vote in person for Federal elections. The Federal Election Integrity Act of 2006 mandates a current, valid photo ID for voting in Federal elections, requiring proof of US citizenship. If ID is not presented, individuals can cast a provisional ballot. The appropriate State or local election official may not determine an individual's eligibility to vote unless the individual presents required identification within 48 hours of casting a provisional ballot. The appropriate State or local election official may not accept any ballot for a Federal election from an individual who votes other than in person without a government-issued photo ID. The requirement for a government-issued photo ID for voting in Federal elections does not apply to overseas military voters. The requirement for a government-issued photo ID for voting in Federal elections does not apply to overseas military voters who are absent from the United States on the date of the election. The text discusses the definition of a government-issued identification for voting purposes, specifying that it must be issued by the Federal Government or a State and require proof of United States citizenship. The text amends section 15483 by changing the heading to focus on providing photo identification and making adjustments to subsection (c). Additionally, a clerical amendment is made to the table of contents of the Act. The amendment focuses on requirements for providing photo identification for the statewide voter registration list, effective from the 2008 general election onwards. Subsection (b) paragraphs (1) and (2) apply to the November 2008 general election and all future Federal elections. SEC. 3. MAKING PHOTO IDENTIFICATIONS AVAILABLE. Requiring States to make photo identifications available for voting purposes starting in fiscal year 2008. Starting in fiscal year 2008, States must provide government-issued photo identification for individuals who wish to vote but do not have one. If a State charges a fee for this identification, it cannot exceed the reasonable cost of providing it to the individual. States must provide government-issued photo identification for voting purposes without charging a fee if the individual attests to being unable to afford it. The identification provided cannot be used for any other government programs or functions. Payments to States to Cover Costs for government administration of elections. Payments to cover costs of providing photo identifications to indigent individuals for voting. The Commission will make payments to States to cover costs for providing photo identifications to individuals unable to afford fees under the program. The payment amount to a State will equal the fees that would have been collected but for certain provisions, based on information provided by the State. The Commission will make payments to States for providing photo identifications to individuals unable to afford fees, based on information furnished by the State. Authorization of appropriations for payments under this part for fiscal year 2008 and each succeeding fiscal year. Amended table of contents includes "Part 7--Payments to Cover Costs of Providing Photo Identifications to Indigent Individuals." Sec. 297. Payments to cover costs to States of providing photo identifications for voting to indigent individuals. Sec. 297A. Authorization of appropriations. Effective Date: October 1, 2007. Passed the House of Representatives on September 20, 2006.
